newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - NZ Business weeklies - June 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - NZ Business weeklies - June 6.

text.p: Judgment threatens personal guarantees: A landmark Appeal Court decision has thrown into doubt the enforceability of personal guarantees given to companies that are later amalgamated. Page 1.
SFO considers cops' computer inquiry: The Serious Fraud Office is expected to decide today whether it will investigate alleged irregularities in police computer projects Incis and Card. Page 1.

Ngai Tahu eyes old post office: Christchurch's former chief post office in Cathedral Square, owned by Telecom, is on the list of properties being sought by Ngai Tahu as part of its nearly-completed $170 million negotiated settlement with the Crown. Page 6.
Arbitrator halves value of Apple Fields land: An arbitrator has ruled that a block of Apple Fields land destined for residential subdivision is worth $3 million and not $6.4 million. Page 9.

Maf wins sole right to regulate and inspect foodstuffs industry: The processed food industry is hailing an agreement between Maf and the Ministry of Health which will streamline a welter of outdated regulations governing production and exports. Page 10.

Chinese visitors assured exports are safe but fruit ban remains: There was little joy for New Zealand in resolving major trading issues with China from this week's visit of vicepremier Zhu Rongji. Page 11.

Wine-box review proceedings go back to High Court next week: The direction of Fay Richwhite & Co's judicial-review proceedings on the wine-box tax inquiry should be decided by Justice Smellie in the High Court on Wednesday. Page 13.

Gov't cracks down on rebel fishermen: The Fisheries Ministry has threatened one fifth of the country's fishermen with the loss of their livelihoods as a fishing industry revolt against government levies brings the industry to crisis point. Page 1.
Forest claimants get $2 million for research: Sums ranging from $2,305 to more than $2 million have been paid to Maori trusts for researching their claims to forestry ownership. Page 2.

Fraud Office's ACC probe focuses on light aircraft: The ownership of a Cessna 402 twin engine airplane is at the heart of a Serious Fraud Office inquiry involving former ACC boss Gavin Robins. Page 3.
Maori cockies keen to export through their own agency: Maori farmers are pressing for the right to bail out of the Meat and Wool Boards to deal through the Maori Export Council (MEC). Page 3.
Blue Star mops up McCollam: Corporate raider Blue Star Office Technology is close to finalising another successful takeover, this time of father/son business McCollam Printers Ltd. Page 6.
